reviewText: Will (Ronnie Kerr, who is also the writer and producer of the film) is fresh out of the Navy after a number of years, and staying temporarily with his older friend, Rich. Rich plays matchmaker, despite Will's protests, and arranges for him to meet the hunky Josh, also a former Navy man. They get off on the wrong foot, until a devastating event forces them together, and somewhat puts in perspective their need for each other.The plot is a bit formulaic and predictable, and the secondary characters - while somewhat realistic - are mostly over-the-top stereotypes. I give the screenwriter props for including different generations of gay men as friends, and the attempt at illustrating the minefields one might encounter in trying to cultivate a relationship. Josh is played by Ian Roberts, a former Australian rugby star who created quite a stir when he came out as gay in the late 1990's. Overall, it is a good effort with capable actors, but I think it fails on several levels, in my opinion. No nudity, likely a light R for sexual references. I give it three stars out of five
summary: Look at attempts to find love, could have been better.

reviewText: I really did try to give it every opportunity. But when the movie mainly consisted of a year's worth of bad parties and two guys who kept missing their opportunity because of a simple disagreement a year ago, and then their best friend, the consummate host of all these horrid parties, abruptly commits suicide for no apparent reason (unless it was the parties that did it,) finally bringing the two guys together for once without having an argument. I don't know, it just felt really forced to me. I mean they went on arguing and disagreeing for a whole year, and now everything is just suppose to fall into place? Life doesn't work that way.Still, I tried to give it a chance because I thought the two guys were... Well, not exactly cute but, sweet! They were sweet. Giganture and his bean. But then, and I know this will sound crazy, given the comment above but I thought they should have given the relationship more time to develop. I mean, when you think about it, they never did. It was just a series of bad meetings over the course of a year, during which they probably said no more than five words to each other, and it was usually the wrong thing, or the wrong time to say it. The only time they ever spent any real time together was in the beginning, at that luncheon which went sour. But you can't build a relationship on that.I don't know. It just irked me. I guess the ending was fair on that point though. I give this a two and a half. You'll just have make up your own minds.
summary: I Wanted to Like This Movie

reviewText: Like others, I found this little flick a huge disappointment. Perhaps, that is because I like Ronnie Kerr and thought he and the story were both good in the flick, "Shut-up and Kiss Me."  This flick (Saltwater) is flat, very flat almost saltine-thin on acting, story, directing, there really isn't much to recommend other than 'caveat emptor' !However, check-out "Shut-up and Kiss Me."  If you're an Amazon PRIME customer, its free, at least for now. Again, you have to be prepared for the low-budget production and somewhat low calorie acting, but the story offers something a bit new on the content scene. There are some funny scenes and Ronnie's performance is so sincere.  Check-out "Shut-up and Kiss Me."
summary: 1 1/2 stars actually--Love Ronnie Kerr, but this one disappoints.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I must just sadly agree with the reviewer above me, this is one of those movies, we may even wonder why they (investors,producers) tried(and,obviously hard)to get made. There's not much of a visible budget, not a personal, or, at least, a professional direction, the dialog is so trite, and, the plot so convoluted in its plain simplicity, you'd wonder why investing in such efforts, or, better, how could it be possible not to realize this mistake, from the get go, just by reading carefully the script itself.I also agree, it would be way too easy, and,simply, not fair, to speak badly of the acting, since the actors are clearly struggling with a whole construction in full disarray!I always try to promote, sponsor, and, buy new independents hoping to have, at least, a simple, but, original movie, or a simple, but poignant, or a simple, but, incisive new directorial debut, or.. somewhat of a movie, even if simple..i mean!Here, there's sadly just a whole lot to cry about, and, nothing else left to any further ambitions.
summary: Not even much of a soap!

reviewText: I will watch Bruce L. Hart in anything. As Rich he brings a breath or much needed energy to this drama. I just wish he had more to do and was more involved with the other characters.  I can't help but wonder if his untimely demise was edited out of this film?  And I think Ronnie Kerr is adorable. And a great actor.  He and Hart work well together. Ian Roberts seems to be unsure of himself and mumbling.  I kept backing up the film to figure out what he was saying. Harsh lighting and inconsistent cinematography marred my viewing pleasure of this indie flick. Colors popping and flashes of light were distracting. As with other Charlie Vaughn directed films he does not seem to be handling the cinematography with ease. The film seems to be taking place in only one side of the room of Rich's (Hart) apartment.  We never see the other side of the room. As with Vaughn's other film "Vampire Boys" it has the same technical issues, not enough coverage and very long scenes with no breaks.  Compelling story though.
summary: My favorite indie stars are in this
Title: N/A

reviewText: 浑水摸鱼 Good opportunity will flash before you faster than lightning.Evidently,  the writer, producer and 1 of the main characters (Ronnie Kerr plays “Will”) in this film have not heard of this “Proverb” because Will’s friend Rich (Bruce Hart) continually and unsuccessfully attempts to get Will together with another of his friends (in real life, former “out” Australian Rugby player Ian Roberts who plays “Josh”). The first attempt was an obvious blind date setup where it seems that the only things the 2 men have in common is that they are wearing the same color shirts and they are both “ex-Navy,” Will from the U.S. and Josh from Australia but from different generations. Whereas Josh’s service was cut short due to a dishonorable discharge for being gay, Will had 20+ years (he must have joined at age 10 as he barely looks 30) of a “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell-type” career. Josh would have none of that and quickly revealed the chip on his shoulder for being thrown out of the Australian Navy. He made it clear that he felt Will was “in the closet” and Will made it clear that “rainbow stickers and parades” are not important to him. Josh asks for the check and so begins several attempts during several holidays to hook these 2 up despite the fact that Will sees no way to reconcile a rough first date.In a way, I can understand Will’s point of view. After several more failed attempts of getting these 2 together, I kept asking myself why on earth does Josh simply apologize for walking out on the first date? Instead, he shows up with different guys he is dating at each successive holiday party. He says he is trying to make Will jealous but were I in Will’s shoes, I too would think Josh has “moved on” and attempt to do the same. Nevertheless, with each party, Josh is obviously obsessed with Will who can’t keep his eyes off of Josh and wonders what “might be” but he is too fearful of further rejection to pursue it. So, now it is Will who has the chip on his shoulder.The movie is chock full of stereotypes from the get go with the flamboyant Rich to gossiping gays, most of whom also seem determined to thrust Will and Josh together and all who know the exact way to do it despite the fact that their lives are a lot less than perfect. There are the usual stereotypical gay sex hounds who have nothing else on their minds other than attempting to end their lonliness by “conquering” any and all who look like they need rescue. To the movie’s credit, one such scene helped to show us the integrity of one of the main characters.There is also the usual “C——Blocker” who is so jealous of a single friend having a date that they will say and do anything and everything to stand between that friend and their date. Some people just feel so damn sorry for themselves (whether they are in a relationship or not) because they are not having “fun” that they will do anything to stop you from having fun. If a friend tries to block your happiness they are no friend.This movie is quite accurate in portraying the dysfunctions of gays and straights alike. The most disturbing is the drinking of an entire bottle of tequila on a dare of who can “hold their liquor.” To its credit however, it provided another opportunity to show one character’s integrity and true romantic intentions.The one totally supportive, and non-intrusive character of Will is Mike (played by Will Bethencourt who also played in “Sober Since,” “Bear City” and “August”). He is HAWT in everything he plays!Will our 2 “heroes” ever get together? In the final analysis I feel this movie is worth it to stick around and find out despite its overall contrived scenes and dysfunctional, stereotypical behaviors. Yes, the “chemistry” could have been better. Yes, the 1 major love scene was kind of lame. However, I have seen a lot worse in this genre so I made it all the way to the end. Although it is not a 5 star film, it certainly is not a 1 star film. I rate it 3 1/2 stars.What does all of this have to do with 浑水摸鱼 Good opportunity will flash before you faster than lightning?Although this movie was full of second chances, seldom, if ever, does a life circumstance give you a second chance. If you are not mentally, physically and financially ready at all times you will miss the opportunities that life offers for happiness. You must risk and trust in yourself to reach out and grab it while it is in front of you. If you lose, at least you tried. If you do not try, it becomes a regret. Do not spend any time grieving what you have lost or what might have been. Move on and be ready next time.
summary: Extremely Contrived Tear-Jerker but I recommend it

reviewText: so i'm in the blockbuster thats closing down n they have their sale of 4.00 for all dvds, so i'm thinking i can find some good gay flicks to take home. i see the cover and read and think 'ok, sounds great!' and of course, its one of the worst acting (the guys r so stiff (not in the good way)) and the one very gay suppose to b comical i guess guy is sooooo unfunny and i have been gay all my life and havent met anyone like this 'queen'. guys in real life dont act or talk like that. and then the 'couple' omg! the one is a very small man compared to a giant of a man and didnt believe their 'chemistry' for a min. so wooden in the acting it was painful. i basically just fast forward through it all but mad that i just flushed even 4.00 down the toilet as i will never watch this dude again and just wanted to save anyone out there who like me, was dupped into buying this for the pretty cover and the info of the storyline in the back. this is a movie filmed at some tiny house in LA and a bunch of friends getting together saying 'hey, nothing else to do, lets play and make a indie flick!' and its soooooo bad!! run away from this one as fast as you can and you can thank me later :)
summary: well i fell for another pretty cover.....one of the worst gay films ever

reviewText: 'Tis a great puzzlement why the majority of gay genre films are so lame and utterly predictable, yet they continue to garner masses of four and five (!) star reviews on Amazon. Today, I have a new theory to explain this weird phenomenon.  I live in a major metropolitan area where the gay men tend to be educated and well read.  They also have plenty of opportunities for experiencing media exploring a vast range of GBLT images.  Such people have zero patience for puerile crap like Saltwater.Apparently, such is not the case out there in The Flyover where all the smart and motivated queers have long since fled hometown provincialism and prejudice for the infinite possibilities of life in the big city.  It's the under-achieving and under-educated gay guys who find themselves hopelessly mired in the small cities and towns of the American heartland where attitudes are not nearly so liberal and open as in the major metro areas, and it's these sadsacks who are the target market for gay pulp movies--very much in the same way Harlequin Romances are blatantly marketed to women who quite possibly chose to have a baby with their sweetheart instead of completing high school or otherwise ended up indentured for life in a minimum wage job.  Only people with limited educations and/or opportunities could possibly believe such lowest-common-denominator escape entertainments like gay pulp flicks or Harlequin Romances are actually good.Yes, I am aware how elitist my theory sounds.  Nonetheless, I find it morally reprehensible that cynical distributors should so shamelessly exploit an unsophisticated audience starving for images of themselves to which they might relate.  Regrettably, the digital revolution in filmmaking has yielded far more dismal, bedroom-edited vanity projects than it has liberated gifted filmmakers."Saltwater" is essentially a silly pastiche of stereotypes, clichés and fantasies pretending it's a movie.  Saltwater sux, as does the system--including Amazon--that distributes a super-abundance of dumbed-down flicks and similar pulp product as serious cinema worthy of a thinking person's consideration.Myself, I feel ripped off for being lured into wasting my time with such shameless mediocrity, but I hope I've at long last learned a critically important lesson:  While I am constantly on the prowl for undiscovered fresh or original indy movies flying beneath the mainstream radar, there are plenty of kinds of movies I've learned how to categorically avoid because they too rarely scratch my itch: Bollywood musicals are never high on my list.  Ditto teen slasher flicks and anything with zombies or vampires.  I just don't go there nor am I even remotely the target market for those varieties of product.  Now I know that anything labeled "gay" is more likely than not schlocky buzzkill, and I need never again bum myself out when my hopes for something clever and original fall miserably short.  Besides, real movies with GBLT themes and/or content already steer clear of the gaysploitation ghetto anyway.  If there's anything good, no doubt word will reach my ears.  Meanwhile, definitely no more flyers on anything labeled gay from neither Amazon nor Netflix.
